Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Accelerating Spectrum Access in Cognitive Radio Networks via Social Analysis of Secondary Users

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental operation for users in cognitive radio networks (CRNs) to access the spectrum is channel rendezvous. After rendezvous is established, channel information exchange and propagation among users are also essential for efficient spectrum access. Existing studies on channel rendezvous in CRNs have limitations and are unsuitable for efficient access scenarios. Additional information about users can help generate intelligent designs in CRNs that can shorten spectrum access delay. However, due to practical constraints, such information is extremely difficult to obtain before rendezvous is established. Mining the social patterns of CR users (or secondary users, SUs) and intelligently utilizing the captured social information is a promising approach. The objective of this project is to design, analyze, and evaluate fast and efficient spectrum access schemes for CRNs without a common control channel. One unique feature of this work is the consideration of SU social patterns and the incorporation of social analysis to enhance spectrum access efficiency. The approach involves analyzing the time, location, and spectrum-dependent social patterns of SUs; identifying and addressing new challenges in channel rendezvous, security, and recommendation designs with the assistance of SU social analysis; and proactively utilizing social patterns of SUs for fully distributed fast and secure spectrum access design.

This project will have a significant impact on efficient spectrum access. Social analysis of users is a critical component to further enhance spectrum access efficiency and accelerate CRN deployment. This interdisciplinary research is potentially transformative as it will help generate innovative techniques to numerous CRN applications. It will also greatly enhance the understanding of social interactions of mobile users in wireless networks. This project provides an excellent opportunity for graduate and undergraduate research students to gain valuable educational training and research experiences. The research results will be presented at IEEE/ACM journals and international conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cognitive radio (CR) technology is a promising technology to overcome the imbalance between the increase in the spectrum access demand and the inefficiency in the spectrum usage by allowing dynamic spectrum access. A fundamental operation for users in CR networks to access the spectrum is channel rendezvous. When CR users want to exchange information, communicate data, or manage spectrum, they should first meet and establish a link on a common channel. This process is called rendezvous. After rendezvous is established, channel availability information exchange and propagation among users are also essential for efficient spectrum access.

The research objective of this proposal is to design, analyze, and evaluate fast and efficient spectrum access schemes for cognitive radio networks (CRNs) without a common control channel. One unique feature of the proposed research is the consideration of social patterns of CR users and the incorporation of social analysis for enhancing spectrum access efficiency. The approach involves analyzing the time, location, and spectrum-dependent social patterns of CR users; identifying and addressing new challenges in channel rendezvous, security, and recommendation designs with the assistance of social analysis of CR users; and proactively utilizing social patterns of CR users for fully distributed fast and secure spectrum access design. This research is the first that systematically incorporates the social analysis of CR users in the design of spectrum access under practical scenarios.

Through this NSF supported research project, we (1)  designed and analyzed a practical self-adaptive rendezvous protocol in CRNs which can adjust its reaction and optimize system parameters to adapt to the dynamic network with practical scenarios including the available channel status changing, collisions on channels, congestion at users, and target users unavailability;  (2) proposed and analyzed a joint design of channel selection and channel hopping for fast blind rendezvous in CRNs which can significantly reduce the rendezvous delay to O(1), thus achieve the goal of fast spectrum access;  (3) proposed a self-adaptive optimal fragmentation protocol for multi-channel CRNs which can guide CR users to derive the up-to-date optimal packet fragmentation in terms of maximizing the throughput;  (4) proposed and evaluated a two-dimensional heterogeneous rendezvous protocol for multi-wideband CRNs which can significantly reduce the rendezvous delay and energy consumption for various rendezvous scenarios, such as pair-wise rendezvous, any-wise rendezvous, and multi-wise rendezvous; (5) proposed a multi-destination blind rendezvous protocol for CRNs which can handle the multiple destination scenario, reduce the overall rendezvous delay, and increase the throughput; (6) proposed and studied topology control and design for time-evolving networks including a set of social-based throwbox placement algorithms, a k-throwbox placement optimization problem, and reliable topology design under unreliable links; (7) studied the efficient sensing task assignment to appropriate participants from a huge user pool, proposed and evaluated both an offline and online algorithm to solve the participant recruitment problem, designed a new dynamic participant selection problem with caching where the cached sensing data is leveraged to fulfill partial sensing tasks in order to reduce the size of selected participant set, proposed a scalable grouping based privacy-preserving scheme which considered the bid privacy protection in auction-based participant selection, and proposed worker-contributed data utility measurement methods and a user filter and recommendation scheme which considered both user interests and data quality for mobile crowd sensing; (8) proposed and evaluated a set of geo-social based routing protocols for large-scale mobile social networks based on our newly defined geo-social metrics which reflect both location and social relationships among users, and proposed an energy-efficient framework for social-based routing (EE-SR) in mobile social networks to balance the load of nodes while maintaining the delivery ratio within an acceptable range by limiting the chances of forwarding in traditional social-based routing; and (9) studied mobile opportunistic data collection based on social behaviors and characteristics of mobile users  and proposed a multi-layer-based opportunistic data collection method which leverages a multi-layer social graph as well as a credit-based incentive-aware mechanism to stimulate selfish mobile users to participate in data collection, and investigated how to provide incentive to mobile users to perform mobile advertisement push tasks via device-to-device opportunistic transmissions, which can be used for spectrum advertisements.

This project provided innovative techniques to numerous applications of the CRN technology, e.g., public safety networks, emergency networks, and cognitive mesh networks. It also has significant impacts on research in emerging technologies with dynamic spectrum access, such as vehicular networks, mobile health, and opportunistic interconnections of heterogeneous wireless networks. This project provides an excellent opportunity for graduate and undergraduate research students to gain valuable educational training and research experiences. The research results are presented at international journals and conferences. Topics on CRNs and mobile social networks with ample inputs from the research work are incorporated into graduate-level courses taught at UNC-Charlotte. The synergy between the topics covered in the course and the research results in this project mutually benefits both.
